text:
I wish I could give this 4.5 stars, because it's dangerously close to a 5-star recipe, but it's not quite there.  I gotta tell you, this recipe is an AWESOME way to sneak in those veggie soy crumbles (looks like ground beef, but doesn't always taste like it...except it TOTALLY works in this recipe).  Definitely make the sauce as suggested by another reviewer (1 tsp sesame oil, 2 T soy, 2 T rice vinegar, 1 T chile paste)...in my opinion, the sauce makes this a 5-star recipe!  I used regular fresh ginger rather than pickled, and shredded some carrots to serve on top of everything.  I would have LOVED to have those nice crunchy noodle-y things, but once I heard they are fried in oil, I had to say "no thanks!"  I'm definitely going to make these again (they're really easy to make, by the way) and will also pass on the recipe!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I've been eating lettuce wrap at many Chinese restaurants since I was a little kid, so I have over 3 decades worth of eating this stuff.  I've tried many different variations and can attest that this recipe is top-notch.  

However, instead of ground beef, most Chinese restaurants use ground pork or duck.  Except for substituting ground beef for ground pork and omitting the pickled ginger (since I didn't have any in the house), I made no changes to the recipe.  As a suggestion, try serving the meat over a bed of crispy rice noodles (vermicelli) as I've seen done in many restaurants.  Simply heat some oil and dunk a small handful of noodles at a time...they crisp up in a couple of seconds.  Not only does it make the presentation nice, it adds a nice crisp crunch to the meat mixture.  

Also, for extra burst of flavour, put a bit of hoisin sauce (see recipe here as well) before wrapping it up in a lettuce leaf, as one other person suggested.

text:
If I could give 7 stars, I would! My variations: I don't like ginger & finding pickled ginger wasn't worth my efforts so I omitted it.  I did add a very healthy portion (perhaps up to 2 tbsn) of Thai sweet chili pepper sauce (looks like a clear gelatin with red confetti in it).  I thought this tasted EXACTLY like PF Chang's, but without the hefty appetizer price.  The key to getting the taste just right, is the sesame oil. (It has a strong flavor & if it's missing, won't quite taste the same as PF Chang's, but don't over do it!)  For serving these as an appetizer, I used the leaves from butter (Bibb) lettuce. They are sturdy enough, but much smaller than iceberg and have a vibrant green color so they make the perfect appetizer ingredient or the perfect size for kids.

text:
I was made this last night for my husband who loves PF Changs lettuce wraps.  In trying to be more like those at PF Changs I used chicken instead of beef.  Since chicken is a bit dryer I doubled all the liquid except the sesame oil (since it's so flavorful).  I also added crushed peanuts and bambooshoots.  My husband was impressed and told me they were just as good as PF Changs.

text:
My sister and I are vegetarians. Yesterday, we challenged ourselves to go a week without bread, pasta, grains, etc.... Very hard to do as we feel that's what fills us instead of meat. I was looking for a good recipe besides our normal pasta, veggie burgers, fruit, and veggies. I came across this recipe and thought that I could make it using Vegetarian Ground Beef (I prefer Boca). It worked out perfectly. I just made it all in one pot. I substituted ground ginger for fresh and left out the chile and chestnuts. Used a little extra soy sauce, and we toasted some sesame seeds and chopped cashews for some crunch. Next time, I think I'll add some bean sprouts.

text:
I used ground chicken and subbed bamboo shoots for the chestnuts bc i wanted the added crunch...they turned out delicious!  I also made extra sauce on the side: 1/4 c plum sauce, a tbsp OJ, 1/2 tsp cornstarch, 1 tbsp teriyaki sauce--boil for 1 minute and let cool.  Spread a bit on the meat mixture when eating--tastes amazing.

text:
I had ground pork in the freezer so I started searching Allrecipes and found this GREAT lettuce wrap recipe. My husband loved it and said it was very impressive. I will place this recipe in my favorites for sure. I did have to add a little more hoisin sauce, because it was a little dry for my taste. The plum sauce and PF Chang sauce recipes posted were the finshing touch needed to complete this recipe. Thank you for the freshing recipe! Plum Sauce: 1/4 c. plum sauce, 1T. OJ, 1/2 t. cornstarch, & 1 t. teriyaki sauce ( I used Soy Vay) boil 1 minute. PF Chang sauce: 1t. sesame oil, 2T. soy, 2T. rice vinegar, & 1T. chile paste ( I didn't have paste, so I used Sriracha Chili sauce) wisk.  YUMMY DISH!!!

text:
I love this recipe!!  Most lettuce wraps call for chicken or pork, which I don't always have on hand.  I use regular ginger and it works great.  I have used a similar recipe that calls for 4 c. finely chopped cabbage, so I added that this time (extra nutrition and makes the mixture go a lot further!).  Also, I make a drizzling sauce of equal parts soy sauce and rice vinegar with a little water, honey, and ginger.  Yummy!

text:
This was a huge hit!  Just a few minor adjustments.  I used ground chicken instead of ground beef and I used fresh minced ginger root. I also used an extra tablespoon of soy, vinegar, and chili sauce.  I served it with shredded carrots and rice noodles.  I also made a dipping sauce that was really good:     *   1/4 cup   sugar     * 1/2 cup water     * 2 tablespoons soy sauce     * 2 tablespoons rice wine vinegar     * 2 tablespoons ketchup     * 1 tablespoon lemon juice     * 1/8 teaspoon sesame oil     * 1 tablespoon hot mustard     * 2 teaspoons water     * 1 -2 teaspoon garlic and red chile paste I am definitely making these again...so good!

text:
My bar is pretty high being Asian and raised in Vancouver with great restaurants, and this was good.  I made it without the chile peer sauce, but instead made a "Hoisin Dipping Sauce" from chinesefood.about.com (spoon it inside before you wrap up the leaf) and it was delicious.  I stir fried the garlic and ginger from the sauce, then put it a bowl with the other sauce ingredients to sit.  Then I used the same pan to cook the Asian Lettuce Wraps beef and so on.  I'm going to be making this one again.

text:
I used this recipe as a base in an attempt to recreate Joey's Grill Chinatown Lettuce Wraps. Instead of beef, I used 2 cut up chicken breasts,  EVOO for the oil, fresh ginger, red wine vinegar instead of rice wine, and plain old iceberg lettuce.  Definitely add the hot sauce (I used Sriracha, the one with the rooster on it). I also added roasted unsalted cashews and topped with cilantro. Joey's wraps have those crispy noodles but I skipped them. These turned out awesome! I have saved this recipe and will make many times in the future! Thanks Rachel!!

text:
This has a fantastic flavor.  I have made it twice now, once with ground beef and once with ground chicken and prefer the ground chicken in this recipe.  In no way is this bland.  I like bold, spicy food and added extra garlic chili sauce to spice it up and offset the sweetness of the hoisin sauce.  I made the recipe as written except used 1/2 tsp ground ginger instead of pickled and increased the chili garlic sauce to about 3 TBL and added shredded carrots and broccoli slaw to increase the vegetables in the dish.   This would also make a great filling for egg rolls.  Thanks for a great recipe.

text:
Made almost exactly as written, including optional pepper sauce. My only sub was ground ginger for pickled, our market had none. The sauce was delicious and I should have doubled it, it simply didn't provide a full enough flavor to the beef. Made with shredded or ground chicken, turkey or pork, a single batch of sauce would likely be fine. Definitely worth making again, although I'll likely use romaine. It'll make a sturdier wrap and provide some flavor of it's own. This was very good, thanks for sharing! ******UPDATE****** Made this again using ground pork. Delicious! I served it with rice and got rave reviews. Have made this numerous times now and have found it's great with added veggies, like red bell peppers, carrots, frozen peas, really anything. It's all good! Really, lettuce is not needed, forks work just fine.

text:
I made very small modifications to the recipe, but I have to say that this recipe was absolutely AMAZING! Instead of ground meat, I used chicken and chopped them up into small cubes. I omitted the pickled ginger and used regular distilled vinegar because I didn't want to buy rice wine. I included about a 1/4 cup of sweet and spicy chili sauce and reduce the amount of sesame oil to 1 teaspoon. I served this up with warm rice and lettuce and I can assure you that I will be making this recipe many more times! Delicious!

text:
This recipe was super easy and extremely tasty. My boyfriend and I agreed it was a much preferred replacement for our usual fajitas, which are not quite as healthy or flavourful. I did alter a few things and the wraps still turned out great. I used soy meat instead of ground beef (easy to cook with because it is pre-cooked, takes on the flavours of whatever dish you use it in, and is a much healthier option). I also used chopped red peper instead of water chestnuts for more flavor but still with some crunch. Finally, I added grated carrots and bean sprouts to be used on top - a great addition! They added extra texture and flavour. I really recommend this recipe, its perfect for every level of "at-home chef" out there!

userID:
1032812
Display Name:
Michelle Roth-Kiva
isPro:

followersCount:
97

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2689406.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yum! These are fantastic!!! Made these for dinner 2nite. My hubby & I have eaten heavy meals w/ friends & family all weekend (it's my Bday). Tonight, I was craving a staisfying, yet "light" meal to balance out all of the calorie-laden ones. :) This more than exceeded my expectations! My hubby isn't even a fan of lettuce wraps, but said these were the best he's ever had (wow!). Rachel's recipe is perfect as is, but I did "tweak" it a bit.... Insted of lean beef, I subbed ground pork (it's waaay cheaper). And, since Rachel didn't mention how much chile sauce to use, I went with 1/2 T. NOTE: I do think pickled ginger is a better choice than fresh. Both have a distinct, yet very different taste (one is pickled - duh!). I ended up finding a small jar near my grocer's shshi section. My grocer was out of Boston bibb lettuce so I used the California bibb variety instead. CA bibb is pretty much the same as it's Boston counterpart, but a paler green color and MUCH better suited for wrapping, IMHO (it's sturdier). Oh, and make the dipping sauce other's have shared in their reviews (2 T soy, 2 T rice wine vinegar, 1 T Sirracha chile sauce & 1 t sesame oil). My hubby and I REALLY enjoyed the dipping sauce. It adds that extra "oomph" that everyone has raved about. Served with a sprinkling of crispy Asian rice noodles, a side of steamed jasmine rice and iced green tea, this was a light, yet incredibly filling meal. Thanks SO much for sharing, Rachel. I'll be making this again soon! :-)

text:
Delish!  As the hubby said, definitely memorable!  I used the sauce that a few people had mentioned (2 Tbsp soy sauce/1 tsp rice vinegar/1 Tbsp sesame oil and added 2 Tbsp chili-garlic sauce instead of "chili paste"...couldn't find that at the store. Oh, and I added about a tsp of fish sauce as well)  I didn't use hoisin sauce as I didn't have any on hand.  

I also added a bunch of veggies:  1 8 oz can water chestnuts, about 1 1/2 cups of mushrooms, 3/4 of a carrot (finely sliced), green onions, fresh ginger, 2 big shallots instead of an onion, and the garlic as recommended.  

I used a lb of ground turkey, browned it in about a Tbsp of sesame oil instead of "cooking oil."  I used a bit more sesame oil to stir-fry all the veggies.

Overall, awesome!!  I will say that the 2 Tbsp of chili-garlic sauce made it spicier...I'm a bit of a puss when it comes to spice.  Any more, and it would have been too much for me!!

text:
This reminded us of an American spin on how an Asian Sloppy Joe might taste. We omitted the cooking and sesame oils to avoid unnecessary fat, forgot to add the pickled ginger, and added the optional Asian chile pepper sauce. Used romaine lettuce as the two types of lettuce leaves suggested by recipe submitter were not available. We had to personalize the seasonings to satisfy our tastes as it was odd tasting without adjustments, and Asian flavor was sadly MIA. Perhaps the Asian ingredients just dont pair well with hamburger which is uncommon in real Asian dishes. The good news is that it brought back fond memories of my elementary school days when the sloppy Joe sauce would dribble down the kids chins onto their shirts and/or laps. Take Rachels advice to have plates and napkins ready to go as lettuce leaves elevate sloppy to a new level.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made the recipe and wanted to add the white noodley things (actually bean threads) for crunch and presentation.  Rather than mess with frying, I was able to "toast" them in the microwave.  The bean threads come in several bundles in a package.  I broke off half of one bundle and separated the threads as much as possible.  On a paper plate, microwave in 30 second intervals, tossing the threads after each interval, for a total of 3-4 minutes or until the threads are crunchy.  Easy, no-hassle way to get the desired crunch and pretty presentation!

text:
I love PF Chang's lettuce wraps, and this is an easy, delicious at-home alternative  I used ground chicken instead of hamburger and "browned" the chicken in peanut oil for more of an asian flavor.  I used minced fresh ginger, but followed the rest of the recipe exactly.  I also used the serving sauce suggested by another reviewer (2 tsp sesame oil, 4 T soy sauce, 4 T rice vinegar, 2 T chile paste) and that definitely was the perfect addition to an already wonderful dish.  I served it to friends and they all loved it and asked for the recipe.

text:
Very delicious! I loved the contrasting textures and temperatures of the lettuce wrap and the meat/veggie mix. I added minced canned straw mushrooms, which were delicious in this recipe, while also adding a meaty texture to make it seem like you have double the meat. The sauce was delicious. I used regular minced ginger because I couldn't find any pickled ginger, though I do love pickled ginger. I didn't bother to buy Asian chili sauce, but I had some regular chili sauce and some leftover spring roll dipping sauce on hand that I added in. I would definitely make this again, even though it was a little bit messy at times.

Loved this recipe! Word of advice though.. use iceberg lettuce instead of butter lettuce. Butter lettuce leaves aren't big enough to eat these without everything falling on your lap. Cut a whole head of iceberg lettuce in half and peel the leaves off. This is how similar lettuce wraps were served at a restaurant I went to.

text:
I used ground chicken to make these more like PF Chang's. The overall sauce wasn't as dark or as thick as at PF Chang's, so for my personal preference next time I'm going to add more pickled ginger, more sesame oil, and probably more hoisin sauce. I decided the fried noodles were a luxury I could save for the restaurant and served ours with white rice and greenleaf lettuce to wrap. Although lettuce wraps can be tricky to manipulate (the sad state of the sorry lettuce I wind up with is what I'm thinking of here), this tastes good eaten with a fork and knife. Dipping sauce optional, but I REALLY like AR's "Sesame Dipping Sauce" recipe & recommend you make a tiny batch of that to serve alongside this meal. Thank you for sharing!

text:
Delicious! Of course I added my own spin on the recipe just like I do everything else. I added a bag of broccoli slaw to the beef mixture to have some extra veggies. I also added ponzu sauce and sweet thai chili sauce to the mix. I never measure my spices so I'm sure I added much more than the recipe called for. I also topped the mixture with crunchy chow mein noodles. It was perfect! Can't wait to make it again. I have a feeling this is going to become a regular craving. I might try it with cabbage leaves next time to do something different. Other meats might be good as well. This is definitely a recipe you can change to suit your taste.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely fantastic!  We loved the flavour and simplicity of this dish.  I used butter lettuce leaves for the wrapping; the filling consisted of 1 lb chicken (thinly sliced), 4 cloves of diced garlic, 1/2 onion diced, sliced cabbage (double amount as onion), 1/2 sliced yellow pepper, 2 handfuls of bean sprouts and 9 shiitake mushrooms thinly sliced.  Sauce was 3 T light soy sauce, 1/4 cup hoisin, 2 T sesame oil and 3 T sriracha for spiciness.  This portion was enough was two AWESOME sidedish meals (for 2 people).  I totally recommend this recipe!

text:
I had lettuce wraps several times at a popular Asian restaurant but had never made them myself til I found this recipe. I must say that it was so yummy! I was a little taken back by the fact that it called for ground beef because I had only eaten the kind with chicken but I decided to follow the recipes advice snd used it anyway. I wad pleasantly surprised at how good it was but I think I will try chicken or pork as well. The only changes I made were omitting the water chesnuts and substituted ground Ginger for the pickled Ginger. When the meat was spiced and done, I turned off the fire and added half a package of rainbow salad (red/white cabbage, carrots and broccoli) to add some crunch. I served it with some white Jasmin rice to complete the meal. I must say that my husband was impressed and raved over it! We will have this again!

text:
Very interesting dish. Great for a hot summer night. My family wasn't impressed but I don't think these are "man food". I liked them a lot and would definitely eat these again. Hubby would too but since they are too different for him he'd like me to only do these once a year. I used ginger paste and chile puree with garlic paste since it's what I had on hand. Used freeze dried chives instead of green onion. Simply delicious and so easy. I still have a tendency though to want to wrap this in a pita or flour tortilla. They're good but it just seems weird eating it without bread. I've made this several times now and it scales down easily. I take this to work for lunch and it keeps well for a couple of days of meals. I'm even getting used to the lettuce idea as a wrap instead of bread : )

text:
Good recipe! When compared to Pei Wei or PF Chang lettuce wraps, it felt like it was missing somethingprobably the extra sauce. But they are still excellent! Minor modifications: I didnt have pickled ginger so I just grated a little fresh ginger. I put a little cooked jasmine rice on the lettuce, topped that with the meat mixture, then finished it off with a sprinkling of chopped cashewsjust to make it a more complete meal. I strongly encourage using the hot chile sauce or paste to kick it up a notch. This recipe is a great at-home version of a popular Asian restaurant favorite!
***Side note: I will probably try using a sturdier lettuce next time. Bibb tore and was a little on the small side.

Wow!  I made just a few changes due to dietary needs and what I had in my fridge and they turned out awesome!

I used ground turkey breast to reduce the cholesterol and fat, and I added some chopped portabello mushrooms and omitted the oil and chili pepper (didn't miss it) but other than that followed the recipe.  I didn't see the need to cook the veggies separate from the meat so I added them in once the meat was mostly cooked.

Also, I made a sauce of soy sauce, chili pepper sauce and hoisin sauce (to taste) and they tasted so close to PF Changs that I'll never order them out again!

Very good!!! I used ground chicken- & just browned it along with the oil,garlic, onion, & water chestnuts. Left out the green onions since I didn't have any. Now I see why so many order them at PW/PF Chang's. (P.S.- Used regular minced ginger in a jar)

text:
I've made this recipe twice now and absolutely love it! The sauce for the meat mixture has wonderful flavor. I didn't do any onions since I don't care for them. I diced up a bunch of mushrooms (portabellas, but others would be good too) and sauteed them up instead of the onions at that stage before adding the beef and sauce. I used fresh ginger instead of pickled as well. The first time I didn't use water chestnuts but I did the 2nd time. They added a bit of crunch but didn't really do anything either way for me so I'll leave them out next time. I added shredded carrots and cucumber on top of the meat mixture in the wrap for freshness and crunch. Next time I will try some chopped toasted peanuts and a little bit of scallions (green part only) for more flavor and crunch. I also made the knockoff PF Chang sauce another reviewer mentioned - that is great! 

And finally, I HIGHLY recommend the butter/Boston/Bibb lettuce leaves. I couldn't find it the first time and used a romaine leaf. They were okay, but too crunchy with the rib of the lettuce. The butter lettuce was perfect and exactly the texture and taste I was craving. Thanks for submitting this recipe - it is now a go-to meal even with my meat and potatoes-loving husband!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/744209.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
What a recipe! The flavor the meat gave off after allowing it to simmer in all the ingredients was really wonderful. I keep myself (and my kids) from snitching it out of the pan. I gave this four stars because one step change (not ingredient) would make this less greasy, as many reviewers have mentioned. Do drain the ground beef- it makes all the difference. Do not, however, sautee the onions in the beef pan without cleaning it out first. This will eliminate the extra grease. Another tip to save time: Once the onions are sauteeing, mix all the other ingredients that go in the pan in one bowl. Then just pour it in when the onions are ready.  We double wrapped our lettuce leaves because they were thin. Lastly, do let it cool down a bit before you wrap up the wraps. Leftovers are good cold! Thanks a million, Rachel.  Will be making this repeatedly.

I made mine useing chopped pork loin and added in some chopped cashews for more crunch then followed the rest of the recipe. Before wrapping I drizzled more Hoisen sauce. But glad I made them.  Maybe next time I will make it up and throw in broccoli and snow peas and lose the lettuce...making them think its more like stir fry, which they love. The flavor of this and the sauce was wonderful.

text:
These were very delicious. The only thing I changed was that I only had Romaine lettuce to use for the wraps. It worked just fine.

Also, I let each person put their own amount of the chili sauce on each wrap by putting the bottle on the table with a small spoon. That way those who like it spicy can have it spicy and those who don't...well, they don't!

Great recipe. For those who can't find pickled ginger, it's also called sushi ginger in the asian aisles of the stores.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was INCREDIBLE!  LOVED it!  It is very versatile as well. I liked this recipe so much that had to write a review despite a few unavoidable ingredient alterations.  I Have never had pickled ginger but the regular worked just fine, Thai garlic paste instead of the Asian chile pepper sauce and regular sesame oil instead of dark. The ingredients are similar so I don't think it altered the taste drastically.  Everything else was exactly what the recipe called for and the flavors were awesome, nothing too overpowering, everything blended very well.  The water chestnuts added a nice little crunch as well!  This recipe is definitely a keeper! I have never been to PF Chang's so I cannot compare but who cares?!! This is an excellent asian dish to make at home without the expense of going out.  FINALLY I have found a recipe for my ground beef that is not swimming in cream of mushroom sauce!  I have to say I am not a real spicy food person so being able to adjust the spiciness was very helpful.  We served it on the boston bib lettuce and layered it with some white rice from my rice cooker.  I used 3# of ground beef and tripled the sauce recipe. We did NOT serve any sauce with it.  The meat is flavored so well I really felt it would distract from the taste. Even the rice did not dilute the taste. Excellent!

text:
These were delish! I accidentally made them a little too spicy for my kids, but they still ate them. I had candied ginger and used that instead of pickled. I also didn't have hoisin sauce so I googled a recipe for that and it turned out very good: 4 Tbsp soy sauce, 2 Tbsp peanut butter, 1 Tbsp honey, 2 tsp rice or white vinegar, 1/4 tsp garlic, 2 tsp sesame oil, 1/8 tsp pepper,  and chinese hot sauce to taste. I just added the whole mixture bc I had a little more than a pound of beef. I will definitely make these again. (A little less spicy though!)

userID:
3243554
Display Name:
LMF443
isPro:
False
followersCount:
36
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
73
favoritesCount:
132
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/416193.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The entire family gave this one a thumbs up and requested to have it again next week.  I made a couple of changes after reading the reviews and to add my own flair.  First, while heating up the cooking oil I added a 1/4 teaspoon of red pepper flakes in order to add a little spice to the meat while it was cooking.  Because an individual I was feeding is allergic to onion, I added a red pepper instead.  I also used fresh grated ginger and a tablespoon of sherry instead of rice vinegar which I like to do in making a lot of Asian dishes because the sherry adds a softer taste than vinegar.  To serve: I put out the lettuce leaves, a bowl full of cashews, a bowl full of shredded carrots, and a bowl full of thinly sliced cucumber so everyone could assemble their own.  Definitely fun, delicious, and different.  Only drawback: a little messy!
Review:
Rating:
4

text:
What can I say? These were, by far, some of the best homemade lettuce wraps I've had. I've made this for me and my wife over a half dozen times and each time it's a great meal. I've made this with ground pork, ground turkey, and ground sausage, with turkey being my favorite version. I have pickled ginger in the house, but have gone to using fresh minced ginger since it adds a much milder flavor. Otherwise, I rarely change this it's so good. I have used the deep fried rice vermicelli and they truly, add a wonderful aspect to the wrap. My toddler daughter could live off those if I let her (but I don't). I have used the meat mixture in steamed dumplings and that has turned out great. You just need to mince the water chestnuts and green onions more so you don't have these odd chunks in your dumplings.

text:
This recipe was really easy to make since I had most ingredients on hand to begin with. I made mine with veggie crumbles - yum! I'd never used hoisin sauce before, so I don't know if I just don't like the flavor or if I got a yucky brand, but I found myself trying to cover up the flavor a bit - not easy, since it's essentially the sauce's base. I added lots of sriracha, extra garlic, and a healthy amount of cashews too. Doubling the sauce is a must. Terrific recipe, easy to make, and impressive final product! Thanks for the recipe - it's cured my PF Changs craving :)  UPDATE: I made these a second time using homemade hoisin sauce, and it was even better. There are more complicated lettuce wrap recipes out there, but why bother? This one is simple, vegan-friendly, and well-liked by everyone who's tried them.

text:
Newbies be warned - if you're trying to make something similar to those famous Chicken Wraps by P. F. Chang's, this is not the recipe to use. That being said, these were still very good. Like many others I also used chicken instead of beef, although I used 4 boneless, skinless chicken breasts and chopped them up small instead of using ground chicken. If you go this route, make sure you add a bit extra of the other ingredients if you'd like a saucier mix. It also doesn't hurt to add chopped mushrooms as you saute the onions. I personally could have lived without the sesame oil - I found out I don't like the flavor while taking little tastes as the meal was cooking.

text:
Used Ground pork  and regular fresh ginger rather than pickled, and shredded some carrots to serve on top of everything.   
Definitely make the sauce  as suggested by another reviewer (1 tsp sesame oil, 2 T soy, 2 T rice vinegar, 1 T chile paste) and green onion slices- might want to double the ingredients.  

Optional  to  make extra sauce on the side: 1/4 c plum sauce, a tbsp OJ, 1/2 tsp cornstarch, 1 tbsp teriyaki sauce--boil for 1 minute and let cool. Spread a bit on the meat mixture when eating--tastes amazing.

text:
This is a fantastic recipe. I replace the green onions with baby bok choi finely chopped. You can blanch the bok choi first you don't have to. You can replace the hamburger with ground turkey or even tofu for a completely veggie wrap. The trick to doing the rice noodles is to boil them just until they are loose and then run them under cold water in a colander. My family likes these served alongside fried potstickers.

text:
Made with ground TURKEY and it was great.  Lots of flavor and even my super-picky kids asked for seconds.  I tweaked the recipe by browning the turkey w/no oil in a separate non-stick pan, but added the oil back in to cook the onions, etc.  I also did not use water chestnuts, so offered shredded carrots in a bowl.  Our toppings also included a bowl of crunchy chow mein noodles (which I think is why the kids were willing to try it).  Definitely adding this one to the "keeper" pile!

This recipe was AMAZING! I took the advice listed here with the sauce and the only thing I changed was to use Braggs liquid amino's instead of soy sauce (It's a soy sauce alternative high in amino acids). Also, I didn't have the crumbled beef so I used chicken breast and cubed it....WOW. it was delish and the sauce...YUM! The only thing I would do differently was really my fault. I served this as dinner and we were still hungry after. I'd double the recipe if your really hungry...

So so good! Also- added some crushed peanut and some crunchy noodles on top before rolling up the wrap.

oh my gosh this was good!! I loved it! and having it in the lettuce to wrap up made it fun and added a contrast of textures. thanks for a great recipe! I will be making this again. maybe weekly...

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2368134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were quite tasty. They reminded me a lot of a hamburger version of the chicken Asian lettuce wraps at P.F. Changs. I used reduced sodium soy sauce and 1 tsp. of minced ginger, I had in the freezer, instead of the pickled which I do not care for. I left of the optional chili sauce in the recipe. For the vinegar and oils I used what I already had to: vegetable oil, white vinegar, and olive oil. I can barely taste any difference in the varieties. I also started making it before I realized I didn't buy the water chestnuts, but I went through with the recipe anyway. I think it just left out a little crunch, but probably didn't change the flavor much if at all. The grocery store I shop at doesn't carry the lettuce suggested, so I bought iceburg lettuce and it worked fine. I chopped off the botton and got 8 nice sized lettuce pieces to use. That is what the restaurant uses where I first tried them at also anyway. Only downside is I liked it just made, but didn't care to eat the leftovers. Although, it was a nice dinner change the evening I made it.

text:
My boyfriend loves to cook Thai food, so we had most of the ingredients lying around the apartment. One day while he was at work, I decided to make this recipe to use up an extra head of lettuce--boy did I make a good decision! The only item I didn't have on hand was pickled ginger, but it's inexpensive and our jar has lasted quite a while--we now make this at least once a month, and it's great every time!  I decided to omit the water chestnuts, since I don't care for them and my boyfriend doesn't care either way. I like spice, so I add the chile pepper sauce, but usually not more than a teaspoon or two, else it's too hot for my man.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is THE lettuce wrap recipe. I was even missing a few ingredients and it was incredible. I only had dried minced garlic so I let it reconstitute in the ground beef while it cooked, then added more to the sauce while it cooked. No hoisin sauce so I used the closest I could find - kung pao sauce which added the spice instead of the Asian pepper. The onions sauteed mildly in sesame oil on lower heat than usual so I didn't burn the sesame oil. It could have used the crunch of the water chestnuts but of course, none on hand. The pickled ginger was replaced by 1/2 tsp ground ginger. When all was cooked I just added the ground beef right into the sauce. Perfect! Just imagine when I get all the right ingredients :)

text:
Great tasting easy recipe.  I took some other reviewers suggestions and used ground chicken and fresh ginger instead of pickled (about 1 tsp grated).  Also used about 2 T of the "optional" chili paste.  I would half the amount of green onion and water chestnuts next time.  Definitely works with the PF Chang style sauce that was recommended (1 tsp sesame oil, 2 T soy, 2 T rice vinegar, 1 T chili paste).  Very good, makes more than you think.

Followed rest of recipe and then added chicken to sauce.  I rarely follow recipes perfectly but other than chicken change everything was very good.

text:
As is, this is great! I altered it the 2nd time to fit into my diet. I sliced chicken breast thin, cooked it on the stove top w/lid and cooking spray, sauce exactly as stated but added a handful of diced vietnamese basil and real ginger. I also add about 1/2 cup of water and let it simmer together for 20 min. We add warm rice to our lettuce leaves and then top with the chicken/sauce mix. MMmmmm and extremely healthy!(minus the sodium of course)

text:
Easy to modify to your own tastes.  Quick to whip up using ingrediants I had on hand.  I used ground pork instead of ground beef.  Ground turkey or chicken would work as well.  I didn't have chile pepper sauce so I added cayenne for a little kick.

You can add other toppings for your lettuce wraps.  For mine, I had julienned carrots and cucumbers, chopped peanuts, more hoisin sauce and some rice noodles tossed with a little peanut oil and rice wine vinegar.  I had all the toppings on a platter and everyone enjoyed making their own wraps.  It makes an appetizer that is full of lively, bright tastes without being heavy.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
All I can say is WOW!  These are just as good as the ones I love at PF Changs.  I had a few changes only because the store did not stock a few of the items or was out.  I can only imagine how out-of-this-world great this will be with everything in it.
Cooking hint:  while the meat is cooking, get the garlic, ginger, soy sauce, hoisin sauce, vinegar and chili in a mixing bowl and ready to add to the onion mixture at the right time since it is a lot to add to a hot pan quickly.  

Changes:  I used ground turkey as it was 9 pm when I shopped and the store was out of ground beef.  I omitted the pickled ginger and rice wine vinegar since the store did not stock these.  I did add ground ginger to taste since I love ginger and didn't want to miss that flavor.  I omitted the chile pepper sauce since I don't like spicy.  
Even with all of these omimssions, the flavor from the meat mixture was amazing.  My husband, when I passed a tasting spoon to him, said that he almost didn't want to swallow it because he wanted to savor the intense and complex flavor of it. 
I will absolutely make this again and again and will head out to a more diverse market to get all of the missing pieces.

text:
Great. I use regular vinegar and ginger powder. I also use ground pork instead of ground beef (many other recipes for lettuce wraps calls for pork). We add bean sprouts, too, and sometimes shredded carrots.

Can also make a nice Thai-style peanut dipping sauce for these (there are some recipes on this site).

text:
My 14-yr old niece and her mom made this for my entire family at our summer vacation (14 of us ranging from 15m to 75). The overwhelming response was "amazing"! There wasn't one person who didn't love this recipe, including my own picky 15m old. I gave her just the meat mixture and rice and she shoved it down voraciously.

Most of my family used the bib lettuce to make the wraps, but a few of the guys ate it over white rice. I think using ground pork or even sliced chicken would be great and I plan to try that myself. Very versatile recipe!

text:
I didn't have all the ingredients.  So for the sesame seed oil I used 2 TBSP of sesame seeds.  I didn't have hoisin sauce but I used 1 TBSP on Sriracha HOT Chili Sauce.  And I didn't have green onions or water cheasnuts so I just left them off.  I used regular vinegar instead of the rice wine.  And I added 2-3 TBSP of osyter sauce since I didn't have the main sauce and I thought it needed to be more liquid to coat the beef.  My husband and I both really enjoyed it (as you can see from our rating)!

text:
Five star-worthy with these changes:

1) Made with ground chicken

2) Made a "special sauce" for dipping. Just mix all these ingredients together:

1/4 cup sugar, 
1/2 cup water, 
2 tablespoons soy sauce, 
2 tablespoons rice wine vinegar, 
2 tablespoons ketchup, 
1 tablespoon lemon juice, 
1/8 teaspoon sesame oil, 
2 teaspoons water, 
1-2 teaspoon garlic and red chili paste

FANTASTIC!!!  We loved the lettuce wraps at PF Changs, and I was thrilled to find a recipe that might substitute since we at there once and only once (we both woke up the next morning with such an MSG hangover we had to swear not to do that to our bodies again).  I can't remember exactly how they tasted to compare the two, but this recipe is WONDERFUL regardless of how it compares to a restaurant.  Good enough we're serving it for the Super Bowl this Sunday.  AND, they're super easy...great for making after you get off work and the family is waiting on you for dinner.  While I was cooking the filling, I though to myself that this isn't THAT much more work than throwing together a Hamburger Helper!  And sooo much better and better for you!

text:
These were okay. I wanted to recreate the lettuce wraps from PF Changs or California Pizza Kitchen. I added shrimp, Shitake mushrooms, shredded carrot/broccoli, and fresh ginger. It was a little on the bland side and was a bit dry. (We did add a little more of the wet ingredients to make up for the additional ingredients.) After purchasing all of the ingredients, this was expensive, so I think we'll just go out for dinner at one of the restaurants instead of making these again. Oh, and be sure to use Bibb or romaine lettuce because iceberg breaks too easily and doesn't have any nutritional value. I thought it was a three star rating, but my husband was happier with it so I gave it a four.

Fantastic dish. I was looking for something new and interesting to do with ground venison - and this was SO GOOD! Very similar to what I've had in restaurants. text:
The ONLY substitution I made was chicken for the beef. They were excellent. I used 4 chicken breasts and simply diced & sauted. 4 may have been 1 too many since the wraps didn't turn out to be as messy as other reviewers described - the mixture came out quite solid and managable. To add some fun, I serve a wasabi ginger sauce on the side (to spoon into the wrap) - that really did the trick! You can find it in the Asian section at your grocery store usually. I will DEFINITELY make these again!!

One of my all time favorite Asian inspired dishes!  I use fresh ginger instead of pickled and omit the green onions due to personal preference.  I also add about a tablespoon of Sriracha for heat. This was a first for me and I will definitely make again.  Since I knew my day might be crazy, I prepped as much as possible the night before because between grating ginger, chopping and needing a lot of ingredients that are not in one place (pantry, spice drawer, frig) it took some time to do that and clean up.  OMG, this made pulling it together MUCH more manageable!!    Did not find them as messy as I expected based on other reviewer comments.  The suggestion to make all together as a salad, is a version we will likely try though.  I added some finely chopped red bell pepper as a garnish.  Might try chopped peanuts the next time, but I didnt have any on hand.

text:
Trying to stick with a low carb, Keto-inspired diet and this is totally Keto friendly! The meat was a little bland for my taste if you stick to exact recipe which is why I did 4/5 stars, but I added a little more of the soy sauce, rice vinegar, ginger and seasonings to taste and we loved it. Used Romaine lettuce which gave it a nice crunch. Next time may do an Asian style cauliflower rice to add to lettuce wraps or as a side. Also, I think chopped peanuts sauted with the onions garlic etc would be another delicious add-on. Will definitely make again!

text:
This was REALLY good and is better than PF Changs IMO. I made it more or less as directed - I did not have ginger, but I did have ginger juice so I added that in stead as well as some roasted sesame seeds. Like others I added fried wontons on top and instead of a wrap, I put it on a salad. Why make it in rotation, I'm not sure - I sauted the onions and garlic with the ground beef then drained out the excess fat. Then added in all the other ingredients with the green onions last. Then I had to walk the dog so it got to sit in the juices for another 15 mins and it was perfect. Thank you so much for a new fave!

text:
This was a great recipe. I modified it by switching ground beef for ground chicken (seasoned with garlic  powder and white pepper) and I added about 8 oz. of chopped baby portabello mushrooms. I  also used low sodium soy sauce. I have a family member who is watching his intake of red meat for health reasons, hence the protein change. The mushrooms helped to bulk up the recipe in a more cost effective method to get additional servings.  Not sure what the nutrition impacts are, but I would assume more beneficial. I have made this modified recipe three times in the last three weeks.  My family loves it.

text:
Still one of my favorites!  Easiest way to make the drop and sugar roll process is to keep the dough super chilled.  I popped the bowl in the freezer between batches so scooping stayed consistently firm. I also roll in granulated sugar instead of confectioners sugar.  The granulated sugar makes a slightly crispier bite and is less cloyingly sweet than the confectioners.

text:
This was a great recipe but I too have my modifications albeit minor ones.  I substituted fresh ginger for pickled ginger and followed the others reviews by increasing the Rice Wine Vinegar and Soy Sauce.  In addition, I also increased the sesame oil to 1.5 tsps for a greater taste.  If you wanted a good healthy crunch topper, add shredded carrots and matchstick cucumbers like I do.  To dress it up even more, I sometimes add chopped peanuts to the mixture.  I neglected to take a picture because it all disappeared too fast.

userID:
20375315
Display Name:
carazeta

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this many times and it has become a family favorite. I don't know what the PF Chang version but this is pretty tasty when you don't have that expectation especially. 

I follow the recipe proportions as written. I substitute turkey or chicken ground meat for beef and both have come out great! I add thinly sliced carrots and cucumbers as well as a few pieces of spinach (raw) at the end once making the wraps. 

Another variation - we found that using lettuce was really messy and inefficient at getting all the good in the mouth so we now use Vietnamese rice paper (found at the Asian grocer) to make actual wraps. My kids love it this way - they can roll their own like a crepe and add as much meat or veggies as they want. It takes practice at home to get it so the wrap doesn't stick to itself like tape but it's worth it. I added a photo of the wraps if interested.
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
Excellent recipe, however it is very dependent on the brand of Hoisin sauce you use.  Like BBQ sauce, every one is different.  We used Asian Kitchen and loved it, then switched brands and were unimpressed.  We like ours with a touch of sweetness.   Anyway, if you dont love your hoisin when you taste it out of the bottle, you wont like a lot better in the dish.  Find one you love, and youll love this recipe!!

region:

country:

text:
This is an easy weeknight dinner (once you get all the ingredients which can be used multiple times-- maybe 5-6 separate dinners)! I omitted the pickled ginger mainly because I was being lazy at the grocery store and had already circled aisle 5 many, many times and didn't want to try finding it. This recipe seemed like it would have tons of flavor anyway and it did! Didn't even notice the missing ingredient. Tips: chop the water chestnuts and onions finely. I also used 85%/15% ground beef and it was a bit too greasy so I definitely recommend leaner beef. Lastly, the grocery store didn't have the recommended lettuce so we used iceberg and it worked just fine. Boyfriend liked the recipe (minus the green onions) so we're going to try it again but next time with ground chicken or ground turkey.

These were amazing... I am definitely making this one again!  My husband didn't love it quite as much as I did (although he still liked it), but in my opinion the flavor and texture for this was just perfect.
I did use romaine lettuce since I prefer it, and also couldn't resist adding some mushrooms to the skillet.
After some initial browning, I put everything for the meat mixture in a slow cooker and cooked it for a short time (1 hr or so) on low so it would be ready and warm when everyone got home, which worked great!

region:

country:
None
text:
I had Chinese lettuce wraps growing up at home and in restaurants, though they always had arrowhead root (not arrowroot) and not water chestnuts. This was probably a better choice for the kids anyway, as water chestnuts are so mild. My daughter is an extremely picky eater, so I added mushrooms to please her. My son INHALED his wraps. I used 1/2 pork and 1/2 beef, and used iceberg lettuce because that's how I've always known it. :) I did have some non-traditional toppings on hand, such as peanuts, sriracha, and Kewpie mayo (Japanese). I also served with sticky white rice, so the kids could put it in the wraps with the meat as desired. Thanks for a good recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really enjoyed this. It was easy to make and very flavorful. Here are my minor changes. I used 4 scallions and no other onion. I cooked the white parts with the meat and saved the green parts for the end. Hoisin sauce is a must for this. That's where most of the flavor comes from. I didn't cook the meat in oil because the meat has its own fat. I kept the fat rather than draining it, so didn't add the sesame oil either. I doubled the soy sauce and vinegar. Used ginger paste and skipped the chili sauce. The only thing I might try next time is drain the fat and use the sesame oil instead.

text:
I did not really love the hoisin sauce in this recipe.  Came out too sweet.  Had to add more vinegar and added some toasted sesame oil to counteract the sweetness.  I agreed with others that it was missing something.   Added fresh cilantro at the end which greatly improved the meat!  Also added fresh ginger in addition to the pickled.   Added about 6 chopped baby bellas with the white onions.    Added a dipping sauce and chopped cashews for topping when serving.  Everyone loved it and it did make for an impressive appetizer.

text:
I didn't make any changes because I like to taste it the way it was written before deciding if I think it needs something else.   We ate it open face on the lettuce leaves because we used this as a main dish rather than finger food.  The leaves aren't really big enough, in my opinion, to wrap a significant amount of the dish.  But I enjoyed it as a alternative Asian dish but still the flavor of stir fry.  My daughter, picky eater, didn't like the flavor of the Hoisin sauce,  but I'm not sure what leaving that out would do to the overall taste.  Maybe I'll try next time and see how that is.

text:
I've made this numerous times now as my family loves it.  I think I could cook it every week and no one here would complain.   I can't find butter lettuce here, but Romaine works great too.  Spice level can obviously be easily upped if you like it hotter, but the recipe as written works fine for my family - a daughter who likes things hot and myself who wants them mild (the lettuce tempers the heat for me.)  We use ground turkey as we don't like beef and that works great for us (and lowers the fat). The only bad part is that there are  no leftovers because even if I make a bigger batch - it's all eaten! Yummy!

text:
This is delicious! I was skeptical, because I've made lettuce wraps before with "Thai" -style sauce of fish sauce, lime, brown sugar, chilies, etc. and really love that, however... Husband, son and I devoured these. I made a few slight changes, though: used a leek instead of an onion, used fresh ginger instead of pickled, added a handful of shredded carrots and made 1.5 times the amount of sauce. Also served on shredded green cabbage because it's easier to eat this way (especially for my son, who has braces). I put out Sriracha and cilantro so we could garnish as desired. Will make this again and again!

text:
I made these using ground chicken rather than ground beef, as per feedback from other reviewers.   There was no Boston Bibb lettuce at the grocery store, so I opted for green leaf lettuce instead.  Unfortunately, the leaves didn't work as wraps (rookie mistake), so I ate my "filling" on a bed of lettuce instead.  And my husband, who loves his carbs, ate his on a bed of rice.  The flavour of this dish is fantastic!  My husband was still talking about how nice this dinner was the next day, which means this recipe has earned itself a permanent spot on our rotation.

*UPDATE*  I made this recipe again, this time with beef.  I am not sure which I prefer - beef or chicken.  Both are great.  This recipe is deceptively quick and easy; no need to be put off by the long list of ingredients.  A definite keeper.

Added extra pickled onions & added cilantro. Yum!

I had no beef so used pork which is more traditional in these wraps otherwise known as Rainbow Ice.  I lost my years-old recipe and after looking through various recipes on the 'net, decided to use this recipe. I actually think this recipe is better - it's very good, nice and moist.   However, one must 'paint' the lettuce leaf with a little Hoisin sauce before placing the filling in the leaf. Even though Hoisin is already part of the ingredients, it makes a difference.

country:
None
text:
My whole family loved this recipe, 8 year old picky son gave it a big thumbs up. Most reviewers used chicken or turkey instead of ground beef- I think all would work just fine. I used 3 cloves of  garlic instead of 2 and threw it in with 2 teaspoons of fresh ginger after I sauted the onion and let those cook for about 30 seconds before adding the sauce. I did make a dipping, which many people recommended: 1 tsp sesame oil, 2 T soy, 2 T rice vinegar, 1 T chile paste and chopped green onion. Great Dinner!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My lettuce wraps tasted great. I followed the recipe but left out the chile pepper and pickled ginger. I sliced the onions (instead of chopping them) for flavor only and removed them just before serving.  I had to add more hoisin and soy sauce, and a little more garlic to add more flavor. Easiest way is to pour directly into the mixture and taste as you go along. You will know when you need more of something.

Go easy on the sesame oil though. I added only what was instructed and I could definitely taste the "oil".

This is 5 stars with the following changes: sauted up garlic and fresh ginger with some zucchini and peppers then added ground turkey. The sauce is made of 2 T rice wine vinegar, 2T fish sauce, 1T Sabah chili garlic sauce, 1 tsp tamarind sauce and 2 T hoisin. Added some cashews and fresh squeezed lime. Served in lettuce with sliced cucumber. So very very tasty. This is going to be a regular. I love dishes that every bite is " this is good".

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Made these for dinner tonight. I made a few changes, like using ground pork instead of the ground beef. We didn't have the pickled ginger, so left that out. I also grated carrots and thinly sliced small cucumbers for toppings. They gave some extra color and healthy additions.  Doubled the recipe, to have leftovers for lunches. Next time, though, I won't double the sauces. A bit too much sauce and salty for my taste. I really like the water chestnuts as they gave a nice crisp crunch to the wrap. This was very easy to put together, especially on a busy weekday night! Thanks for sharing this recipe on Allrecipes.

text:
You need to modify it to love it. Most reviewers added to it, so I took notes & this is what I did:  I made the recipe exactly as written (except I didn't have any water chestnuts). My intention was to make one of the reviewer suggested dipping sauces. When I tasted the recipe, it was ok, but far from awesome, so I added the dipping sauce ingredients right to the recipe & let the sauce created thicken in the meat. SUCCESS!! Added to original recipe: 1 tsp sesame oil, 2 Tbsp soy, 2Tbsp rice vinegar, 1Tbsp chili garlic paste (label has a rooster & you can see the pepper seeds), 1/2 tsp sugar, 2 additional garlic cloves. As written, it's a 3 star recipe, but if you take time to read reviewer comments, you can improve most recipes.

Display Name:
GALA62

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/72323.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A really great base recipe to "play" with. Like several other reviews, I wish I could give it 4.5 stars. But I made a few too many tweaks to warrant a 5.

Definitely use ground turkey or chicken - I think beef is far too fatty for this recipe, plus they're healthier. Be sure to break up the meat into very small pieces while it's cooking. I used fresh grated ginger instead of the pickled.

Instead of adding the veggies to the cooked meat (except for some onion), I prepped them to be added to the lettuce "packages" before eating. I used sliced water chestnuts, finely sliced carrots, thinly sliced radish, sliced scallions, matchstick cucumbers and thinly sliced onion (all uncooked).

I spread a very thin amount of hoisin on each lettuce leaf before adding the meat to help it stick (I used a pastry brush), then added the veggies and rolled each one up. Absolutely delicious!

text:
I've been making this while on my Daniel Fast so of course I've had to make changes to the recipe. I used garbanzo beans (3 cans)in place of the ground beef, one small yellow onion, about a Tbsp of minced garlic, about 4-5 Tbsp of soy sauce, one bunch of green onions, a Tbsp of Smucker's Natural Chunky Peanut butter, a dash of black pepper, and the waterchest nuts. I followed the directions for onions and then added the other ingredients. I added about 3 Tbsp of Szechuan Spicy Stir Fry Sauce at the end to give it a kick. Tastes great and has become a regular staple when I do my fast or am looking for a vegetarian night.

text:
I've never had Asian lettuce wraps before so I have nothing to go by, but these were excellent! I did use ground pork per recommendations, but it would be great with whatever meat you choose. Only had dried ginger so went with a few shakes of that. Made a double-batch of a sauce recommended by the second reviewer and others (soy sauce, rice wine vinegar, etc) and drizzled that over the meat mixture before rolling. Had some sweet chile sauce on the side for dipping, as well. Used iceberg lettuce (had on hand), and it was quite messy making a wrap. Will try one of the other recommended lettuces the next time. Thanks Rachel, excellent recipe!

text:
I think it would have been a 5 star recipe if I followed it exactly and I rated it as such.  I didn't have the chili pepper sauce or the sesame oil or the pickled ginger, so I grated a large carrot, diced 2 stalks of celery, diced 1/2 medium red pepper and added 4 more minced cloves of garlic and 2 tablespoons more of the hoisin sauce, 1 tablespoon more soy sauce and about 3/4 teaspoon of powdered ginger.  My version was a 5, in my opinion.  Thank you, Rachel, for the recipe!

country:

text:
My husband said this was one of the best dishes I've ever made.  I do make a couple of changes:  I use a whole boneless chicken breast that I rub with a touch of soy sauce and sesame oil and saute whole in a tsp or so of vegetable oil until barely cooked through.  I then chop into pea-size pieces once cool enough to handle.  I also add half a can of straw mushrooms (chopped), fresh ginger in place of the pickled, and a tablespoon or so of Mirin & a splash of tamari sauce.  I do increase the stir fry sauce amounts to account for the extra meat as the chicken weighed over a pound...  REALLY GOOD RECIPE!!!!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Made this last night...excellent.  Used ground chicken and added about 2 tablespoons water, 1 tablespoon (each) extra soy sauce and hoisin sauce. (Ground chicken is dryer than ground beef)  I also used only about 4 oz. of the chopped water chestnuts; as that seemed like enough when I was adding it in. I don't think I would add any more than 4 oz. when making it again.  I added onion and garlic powder and some black pepper.  I chopped some cashews and grated a carrot for toppings and they made a very nice addition. I made some brown rice to go with (I was worried that my iceberg lettuce would not be a good substitute for the bibb lettuce)  We enjoyed it both as a lettuce wrap and with the rice.  I  served it with a  ginger salad, so it was an entre and not an appetizer.  I was very impressed with the flavor and texture of this dish.  I will make it again and soon!

text:
Really good flavor if you use the pickled ginger et al. I really like using the Bibb Lettuce, though as it suggests, with ingredients, does get a little drippy. It's very tasty...and a definitely unusual "finger/hand food" for many of us simple 60 year old guys (too messy). I put it in a "Caseydilla", topped w/ some mozzarella to bind the  tortilla...did this for 98 yo Dad. Made it easier to eat and he said the flavor was really great. I used half pork and half lean ground chicken plus a dash of fish sauce. It has a little bite to the seasonings as well.

I made a small change to this recipe.   I used minced ginger instead of pickled ginger because I already had the minced ginger in the fridge and pickled ginger was expensive for needing only 2 teaspoons. text:
This is a great recipe for a variety of occasions, and can easily be made grain/gluten-free (we used gluten-free hoisin & raw coconut aminos for the soy sauce).  My kids loved it, and they're quite picky.  A number of tweaks have been proposed in these comments, and many seem worth trying out next time, but this is a great basis for a new regular dish that can be individualized over time.  Thanks!  Oh, P.S. - being grain-free they get devoured quickly...consider having a filling side, or make more than you think.

text:
Delicious.  I thought ground beef sounded kind of weird, so we used chicken.  We omitted the water chestnuts and added sesame seeds.  I was really disappointed I was out of ginger, but it tasted great without it.  Also, I made my own hoisin  sauce using a recipe I found online that was basically soy sauce, peanut butter, garlic, and sesame oil.  I couldn't find any of those white airy noodley things that I wanted for crunch, but it didn't matter, this was good enough on its own.  Also, I followed someone else's advice and did green onions instead of white.  I didn't cook them, just put them right on top with the carrots.  Even my five-year old ate this up.

I changed the recipe a little, so I'm only giving it 4 stars.  It was very good and both my husband and I enjoyed it.  I could not find bibb or Boston lettuce and frankly, head lettuce just doesn't work.  It tore something awful, so that part didn't really work out.  We ended up serving the mixture over Udon noodles that I made.  I used ground chicken, added some seasoning salt (along with the other seasonings the recipe called for) and added shredded carrots, too.  I think it made a nice version, and cheaper one, too, of Noodles and Company.  I will make this again, and next time will add snow peas to the mix.

Very good, I followed the recipe exactly except for substituting the ground beef for the ground chicken breast.  It turned out really well and we all loved it, even the kids.  Based on my experience with Asian cooking/food, I think it would be best to add sesame oil at the end when you turn the heat off or you lose the fragrance/flavor of the sesame oil.  And you only need 1 teaspoon and that would cut the calorie down as well.

text:
the second time i made this i quadrupled the pickled ginger, along with adding fresh AND powdered ginger. i felt the flavor got lost in the myriad the first time. i also threw in half a red bell pepper and a zucchini, diced, with the onions in the beginning. this added a new aspect of flavor and made the dish more filling. it's great for parties, set out the bowl of meat with a bowl of grated carrots and another of bean sprouts, spread the fan of lettuce leaves around and let everybody build their own while you listen to the compliments :)

userID:
3339716
Display Name:
AddyK
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

0

10

106
recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/145723.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Oh My Goodness!  What a nice treat to be able to have restaurant tasting Asian food in my own home!!!!  My husband wanted to make these for me with some store bought Miso soup.  The only thing he did different was: minced a boneless/skinless chicken breast into very small pieces and saute in oil/sesame oil in the wok.  Also, he used fresh ginger rather than the pickled.  Lastly, he did use the chili sauce.  I have to say, that was the best part of it.  It gives the sweet heat (these are not too spicy, don't worry) that really takes these wraps over the edge!  I topped mine with the crunchy rice noodles...YYYYUUUUMMMMYYY!!!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2010-03-07T11:05:38.387
helpfulCount:
0

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Very good! This recipe just like what I've had in restaurants. The only things I will make sure to do next time is watch the chili sauce. I used 1 tbsp Sriracha chili sauce for half a recipe and I was on fire. I love hot, but I'll start with a tsp next time and go from there. Also, buy the right lettuce. I stuck with iceberg since I had it on hand and it was hard to keep together, let alone get a whole leaf peeled off. While assembling, I spread a bit of hoisin on the lettuce (plum sauce would work too), then the meat mix (used veggie crumbles), and topped it off with angel hair noodles and julienned carrots. I will definitely make this again.

text:
I thought this recipe was very good.  I followed it exactly and was pleasantly surprised.  I was skeptical about the ground beef, but don't like to modify a recipe before I try it the way it is written.  My only question is the type of chili sauce they used.  Many reviewers mentioned the final product being sweet.  I noticed several different types of chili sauce at the store and went with the more traditional version, which is not sweet.  Since I used a spicier type chili sauce, mine was pretty hot.  I will half the amount next time so that my son can eat it too.  Mine was definitely too spicy for his taste, but I loved it.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I took Pima's advice from a few years ago and made the two dipping side sauces. First, the one a lot of people have already posted - 2Tbs Soy, 2Tbs Rice Wine Vinegar, 1Tbs Chile Sauce and 1tsp sesame oil. The Second, my favorite,  1/4 cup Plum sauce, 1Tbs O.J., 1/2tsp cornstarch and 1tsp Teryiaki sauce- put all 4 ingredients into sauce pan and bring to a boil for one minute. These are always a hit whenever I serve them, I prefer to use fresh ginger and ground chicken.

text:
I'd had lettuce wraps at a Chinese restaurant the day before, and so was inspired to make my own.  Maybe that's why I'm giving this recipe 4 stars instead of 5 - they weren't quite as good as the ones I'd just had.  But overall, very tasty and not too complicated to make.  I substituted ground chicken for the beef, bamboo shoots for the water chestnuts, and used real ginger root, peeled and cut into slivers.  These were flavorful if a bit messy to eat, and just as good - if not better - the next day.

text:
I wish I could give these 4.5 stars!! I followed the recipe exactly, only subbing the ground beef for ground chicken and the pickled ginger for 1/2 tsp. of ground ginger. I also used about 2 tbsp. of Sriracha chili sauce. Served with crunchy rice noodles and shredded carrots. Turned out great and came together very quickly! Excellent week night meal. *UPDATE* Since these can be quite messy, I've started turning them into salads. Lay down a bed of torn lettuce leaves, pile on the meat mixture and top with shredded carrots, cucumber and chopped peanuts. Much easier!

text:
I am giving these a four only because I have eaten these at a restaurant before and these will probably take much experimenting before mine taste as good as those (if I can EVER match the restaurant ones). However, my family loves these and we have made them several times. My husband has never had the restaurant version, and so he has no comparison. He requested these again after I had made them the first time. He took leftovers to work for lunch and kept talking about them again the second day when he came home from work. Can't wait until I find the exact taste from the restaurant. I will share if I do. Also, I have made these with both ground beef and the second and third time with ground pork because that is what I had on hand. Both ways were equally good to us. UPDATE: Just made these again (for like the 50th time or something like that), and these were the best ones I have ever made. Only thing I know I did different was to add a can of sprouts just because I had them and thought I would try it. Also, made the vegetarian version for my daughter using shrimp. They both tasted awesome. Used ground turkey in our non-veg version. Not sure if it was the sweet chili sauce or a different Hoison sauce brand. I did also add one drop of my ginger essential oil! They smelled awesome after the drop of oil too! (Caution: You have to be careful, you cannot just use any old essential oil! Some have harmful fillers. It has to be one that specifically lists the supplement facts.)

Both my husband and I thought these turned out great! I would have given this 5 stars, except that I tweaked the recipe bit... 1) I used ground pork, 2) I didn't have Hoisin sauce, so I used Oyster sauce, 3) I used minced fresh ginger rather than pickled ginger, 4) I added 1/2 tsp white pepper, and 5) I chopped up a few sprigs of fresh cilantro and added it at the end of cooking.  The lettuce wraps were DELICIOUS!  Although there are only two of us, there were no leftovers from this recipe!

Ten stars from my family and I. I used extra lean ground chicken breast instead of the beef for a healthier low fat wrap. I didnt have any ginger on hand, but will add next time. I also added shredded carrot and very thin sliced red peppers to the mix. Used iceberg lettuce and had no problems, might try bibb lettuce,too. So very flavorful and delicious. We all scarfed them up watching the super bowl last night. Will make again soon!
Review:

text:
This is without a doubt the best recipe i have made on this site, pf chang's eat your heart out.  I did as directed except i did not have any ginger this was worth every ingrediant in it.  I was in fat hog heaven eating them.  It made a lot too wow i should have cut it in half but i plan to eat it all.  I dont know why people said it was dry mine was so not dry.  I used gound beef chicken and pork mixture and cooked that with onions at one time drained, then put everything else in the pan stirred to coat and them put in a bowl to set.  Perfect!!  i also made the oriental dipping sauce that a couple people mentioned just in case it was dry but it wasnt that sauce was the bomb too.  I dont think words will do this recipe justice Thank you thank you thank for a wonderful dinner.

None
text:
I made this with shrimp, and it was excellent. I chopped the shrimp before sauteeing, but next time I'll sautee them whole and then chop them to a finer texture in the food processor, because the bigger pieces kept falling out of the wraps. I'll also add some soy sauce to the shrimp. I thought this would taste oniony, but it didn't at all. The ginger and hoisin really stand out, and the water chestnuts give it a great crunchy texture. I didn't have enough hoisin, so I added some sweet and sour sauce and ponzu sauce. I can't wait to make this again.

text:
I made this using Yves' Ground Round (a tofu based meat substitute that is surprisingly meaty) and like other reviewers, upped the sauce quotient a bit and used fresh ginger, not pickled. Maybe because grating it is such a lovely, aromatic experience! I also added about 1.5 cups of rinsed bean sprouts for some extra crunch. We serve these with edamame on the side. A great, healthy, vegetarian meal. Wrapped small and secured with a toothpick, these would be great appies as well!

This was positively fabulous....I did make a few changes;  
1) I used a mixture of pork/beef 2) Couldn't find pickled ginger so I used grated some fresh ginger; 3) These are really messy, so to make the wraps more "hand friendly", I prepared the wrap as the recipe indicated (use iceberg lettuce!).  THEN, I wrapped the whole thing in a soft tortilla.. Viola :-)

text:
I like this recipe as a basic.  The last time I made it I added one-half cup of peanut butter to the actual mixture.  It gave it more of a Thai taste; everyone loved it. Also, when I serve it, I always have peanuts on the side for each person to spoon onto their wrap to add some texture and crunch (if you don't feel bold enough to add the pb to the mix, this is a nice addition to the original recipe).  The chile pepper sauce is a must, which I also serve on the side so each person can spice it to their liking.
